issues.text: whether the subjectmatter of the legislation in Act No. XXXVI of 1947 was exclusively in the Provincial List, and that section 107 2 of the Government of India Act and article 254 2 of the Constitution which apply only with reference to legislation on subjects which are in the Concurrent List, have no application

anchor.surface_text: The question of punishment for contravention of orders under the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act both under Act No. XXXVI of 1947 and under Act No. LII of 1950 constitutes a single subject. matter and cannot be split up in the manner suggested by the learned Judge.

holdings.text: We must accordingly hold that section 2 of Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947 cannot prevail as against section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act No. XXIV of 1946 as amended by Act No. LII of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that section 2 of Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947 cannot prevail as against section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act No. XXIV of 1946 as amended by Act No. LII of 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act LII of 1950 comprehensively covers punishment for contraventions including enhanced cases; constitutes same subject-matter as Bombay Act XXXVI of 1947; later central law prevails under art 254(2) via implied repeal as both cannot stand together.

holdings.text: Act No. LII of 1950 is a legislation in respect of the same matter as Act No. XXXVI of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, entirely in agreement with the opinion of Chagla J. and Chainani J. that Act No. LII of 1950 is a legislation in respect of the same matter as Act No. XXXVI of 1947.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preamble of Bombay Act shows enhancement of penalties; Act LII recasts s7 grading punishment by commodity and offence type including 7-year term for hoarding foodgrains over limit; covers entire field of punishment unsplittable.

holdings.text: The question of punishment for contravention of orders under the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act both under Act No. XXXVI of 1947 and under Act No. LII of 1950 constitutes a single subject-matter and cannot be split up.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Punishment is unitary subject; cannot distinguish enhanced vs normal; later statute re-describing offence with different punishment implies supersession per settled construction rule.
